importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the Paris Climate Agreement, marking a pivotal moment in global climate policy and setting the baseline for future climate projections.
The reference point for the 1991–2020 climate baseline used in defining 'superhot days'.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The long-term projection period used in the study to estimate future superhot days under current climate trajectories.

keyTakeAways: Climate change will result in an additional 57 superhot days per year by 2100, even under current emission commitments, which is half the increase from the pre-Paris 4C warming scenario.
Before the Paris Climate Agreement, global warming was projected to reach 4C, resulting in 114 extra superhot days annually; now, with 2.6C warming, it's 57 extra days annually.
Since 2015, the world has already added 11 superhot days on average.

The impact of climate change is highly unequal: small island nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa face a dramatic increase in superhot days, with Panama projected to see 149 more per year.
These 10 most affected countries collectively produce less than 1% of global carbon emissions.
In contrast, top emitters like the United States, China, and India — responsible for 42% of global CO₂ — face only 23–30 extra superhot days.
This disparity highlights a global injustice in climate impacts, potentially fueling geopolitical instability.
Experts stress that tens of thousands or millions of people will be affected by dangerous heat, with thousands dying annually in heatwaves.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new study by World Weather Attribution and Climate Central reveals that even under current global climate commitments, the planet will face 57 additional superhot days annually by 2100 — nearly two months of dangerously high temperatures — due to climate change. This represents a significant reduction from the pre-Paris 4C warming scenario, which would have added 114 such days. However, scientists emphasize that the impacts are deeply unequal: small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa face dramatic increases in heat exposure — with Panama projected to gain 149 extra days — while major emitters like the United States, China, and India face only 23–30 more, despite being responsible for 42% of global emissions. Experts warn that such disparities exacerbate global inequalities and could fuel geopolitical tensions, with tens of thousands or millions of people at risk of health impacts from extreme heat, especially in vulnerable regions.
title: Climate study finds overheating world will add 57 superhot days a year
